hints.content: Start by understanding how to identify an island in the grid. An island is formed by positive integers that are connected either horizontally or vertically. You can use Depth-First Search (DFS) or Breadth-First Search (BFS) to explore and mark the cells of an island.
Remember to keep track of visited cells to avoid counting the same island multiple times. You can maintain a separate 2D boolean array or modify the grid itself to mark visited cells.
When you encounter a positive integer, initiate a search to calculate the total value of the island. As you explore, sum up the values of the cells that belong to the island.
After calculating the total value of an island, check if this value is divisible by k. Use the modulus operator to determine if `totalValue % k == 0`.
Consider edge cases where the grid may contain rows or columns filled with zeros. Ensure your algorithm correctly identifies islands in such scenarios.
If the grid is empty or contains no positive integers, the output should be zero. Make sure to handle these cases before starting the main logic.
Think about how you will traverse the grid. You can iterate through each cell, and whenever you find a positive integer that hasn't been visited, trigger the island search.
As you implement the DFS or BFS, ensure that you only move to adjacent cells that are also positive integers. This will help in accurately forming the island.
Once you have the count of islands whose total values are divisible by k, remember to return this count as your result. Keep track of the count using a simple integer variable.
Finally, consider the performance of your solution. Given the constraints, your algorithm should ideally run in O(m * n) time, where m is the number of rows and n is the number of columns.

questionNotes: An island is defined as a group of positive integers connected 4-directionally.
You must return the count of islands with a total value that is divisible by k.
The grid can be as large as 1000 x 1000, so efficiency is important.
Ensure you handle cases with zeros correctly, as they do not contribute to islands.
The total value of an island must be calculated before checking divisibility.
